name: stichting Groningen Declaration Network
membership: The GDN as such holds no membership in other associations/(con)federations/networks but its participants represent well over 400 organisations worldwide which  often advocate the GDN in their own networks, particularly its signatories (82 as of 20 April 2018).
goal:
The objective of the Foundation is:

To develop, offer, support and advise on the subject of Digital Student Data Portability (DSDP), particularly concerning the mutual consultation on an exchange of information between all parties worldwide and institutes for higher education in particular;

To develop and offer best practices and globally accepted standards for safe and citizen oriented mutual consultation and the exchange of information on the subject of DSDP;

and everything related, belonging or conducive to this in the broadest sense.

The foundation seeks to achieve its object by:

Creating and facilitating a network for the foundation’s object;

Bringing together stakeholders in the area of DSDP;

The use of multimedia for the foundation’s object;

Generating publicity by any means for the foundation’s object;

The acquisition and provision of resources (financial or otherwise);

And also doing everything directly or indirectly related to this, in the broadest sense.

The foundation is not intended to generate profit.
interests: Competition, Digital economy and society, Education and training, Employment and Social Affairs, Trans-European Networks
euInitiatives:
Citizen Centredness has been one of the guiding principles of the GDN right from its start (as a virtual network) in April 2012. Thus, the GDN has routinely sought to initiate conversations with various Directorates-General of the European Commission, foremost with - in alphabetical order -the DGs CONNECT; Digital Single Market; Education and Culture; Employment; and Justice. Several spokespersons of these DGs have attended GDN meetings and contributed to the conference programme by submitting video messages and interventions. This way the GDN systematically provided several D.G.s with an overarching view that transcended sectoral policies. To the GDN, educational data accompany a citizen not just within the education sector but remain relevant during a person's professional career. The issues that matter the most here are listed in the Groningen Declaration itself: Ownership of data;privacy; authentication; interoperability; and recognition.

Many of these same issues are now being addressed in new EU policies, amongst which:

- the Digital Education Agenda
- Erasmus+ after 2020
- the European Education Area 2025
- the Sorbonne Process

Building on seven years of outreach and dialogue with the Commission, the GDN continues its efforts to influence the design of Erasmus+ after 2020, in order to ensure that the programme promotes the digital portability of student data (learning agreements, transcript of records and other credentitials) in line with the principles laid down in the 2012 Groningen Declaration.

For these purposes, we write position papers, take the floor at EU events, invite EU officials to speak at our events, visit officials in their offices to discuss policy and practice.
